name: Monday Python Club

short_description:
Here’s one for the gamers – get down and creative with Python, and develop your own game!

 

Games Programming with Python I

 

Description

Python is one of the most popular languages out there. We will be using it to create art and games in our typical fun and creative blue{shift} way.

Come prepared to make awesome video games and come with your own ideas about how to make them even better!! You’ll learn the basics of programming while you’re at it.

Pre-requisites

It is recommended that children enrolling in our Games Programming course have an understanding of basic programming concepts (i.e. they have done at least two terms of a visual programming language such as Scratch).

 

Laptops

We operate a BYOL (bring your own laptop) policy. We will have a few laptops available to borrow for those who absolutely cannot get their hands on one.. Please be in touch should you require one.

 

Topics covered

  • Creating game loops
  • Creating game player inputs
  • Python syntax
  • Video game design
  • Screen design and presentation

 

Software used

All software required is free! We will need PyGame and the PyScripter IDE but can help you install this before or on the first class.

Students will go home with a copy of the games they’ve designed on a USB stick.
description: Here’s one for the gamers – get down and creative with Python, and develop your own game!

name: Kensal Rise Club: Python Programmers

short_description:
Monday Games Programming

Course Description

Ever wanted to figure out what it takes to make your own computer games?

We will start off our Games Programming course by making our own versions of the classics — old and new– in Scratch. We’ll get creative together, reinventing games like Flappy Bird and Space Invaders. We’ll populate them with our own characters and write our own rules.

Our young games programmers will discover how easy it is to code using Scratch’s block-based interface to create games and animations. We will import and manipulate images and sounds and will use problem solving skills and critical thinking in order to achieve desired outcomes.

Since this course is geared to boys aged 8 and above, if we find that everyone has mastered Scratch before the term is through, we will start the children on games programming with Python.

Python is one of the most popular languages out there and a favourite amongst educators and programmers for its relatively forgiving syntax structure. It’s also incredibly useful and fun!

 

Achievements and outcomes

Our dedicated teachers will guide each student through a set of projects which will enable each child to learn the main computational concepts and then later to apply those concepts to build games which incorporate many of the topics covered below.

 

Topics covered

• X-Y coordinate systems
• Graphical sprites: the basis for any games
• Input/output using strings
• Use of audio files
• Algorithms: concepts and application
• For and while loops

 

Pre-requisites

Students do not need any previous experience, however, those with previous Scratch experience will be challenged appropriately.

 

Laptops

We operate a BYOL (bring your own laptop) policy. We will have a few laptops available to borrow for those who absolutely cannot get their hands on one.. Please be in touch should you require one.

name: Portobello Games Programmers

short_description:
Crafty  Coders

 

Course Description

Welcome to the world of coding!

Our Crafty Coders will discover how easy it is to use Scratch’s block text to build code that will allow them to create fun projects and games.

They will get to import and manipulate images and sounds, but will have to challenge their problem solving skills and use critical thinking in order to achieve their desired outcomes.

Students will learn how to speak to the computer; they will begin to understand what computational thinking means, and identify the logical steps needed to give a computer a command to execute.

 

Scratch is a great tool for allowing young coders to adapt their code quickly and to test things out at all times. The code blocks enable students move code around and try altering values to see what happens, we find this very important for students to feel in control quickly and keep their interest developing in computational thinking and coding.

 

Achievements and outcomes

Our dedicated teachers will guide each student through a set of projects which will first enable each child to pick up the main computational concepts and then later to apply those concepts to build games which incorporate many of the topics covered below.

 

Topics covered

  • X-Y coordinate systems
  • Ease of using the computer
  • Graphical sprites: the basis for any games
  • Input/output using strings
  • Use of audio files
  • Algorithms: concepts and application
  • For and while loops

 

Pre-requisites

This is an introductory course and students do not need any previous experience.

Laptops
We operate a BYOL (bring your own laptop) policy.

name: After School Club: Crafty Coders

short_description:
**This club is open only to students of Chepstow House School**

blue{shift} teaches children to create technology not just consume it!

Being able to program computers is a skill critical to success in the world of the future. Not only is it a critical skill but it is a creative endeavour which teaches problem solving and analytic thinking. The younger children learn to code and the more practice they gain, the more fluent they will become in ‘computational thinking’ and the better their chances to excel.

Junior club (Year 2/3) 
Mondays, 15:45 – 16:45
Children in the Junior club will build a foundation in computing by using code to create their own games and stories using Scratch.

Senior Club (Year 4/5)
Tuesdays, 15:45 – 16:45
Our Senior coders test out their coding chops by creating games and stories using text-based coding (a more grown up version of what the Junior coders will be doing). We will be using a version of JavaScript that has been created just for kids. We will also be testing out the new and super cool BBC micro:bit to see how we can program lights and sensors. We may even make our own ‘wearable’ bit of computing — fancy a light up LED hat anyone?

Touch Typing Club
Wednesdays, 15:45 – 16:45
In this club we will be preparing new coders for their move from block-based coding to text-based coding by learning to type with fun games and activities!

name: After School Club: Chepstow House School

short_description:
**This club is open only to students of Harrodian. At the moment, it is only open to Year 2 students**

blue{shift} teaches children to create technology not just consume it! Next year, we will be designing and building our own incredible video games and web pages. We will also be doing some really cool stuff with robotics, using computers to control motors and sensors.

Being able to program computers is a skill critical to success in the world of the future. Not only is it a critical skill but it is a creative endeavour which teaches problem solving and analytic thinking. The younger children learn to code and the more practice they gain, the more fluent they will become in ‘computational thinking’ and the better their chances to excel.

blue{shift} focuses on project-based learning which is the way technology is built in the ‘real’ world.

Scratch programming
Children in the club will make games using Scratch (an amazing tool developed at MIT for the purpose of introducing children to programming; it’s even used in introductory Computer Science classes at university) We will be using music and art to inspire our work.

name: After School Club: The Harrodian

short_description:
Robotics and coding club

Have you ever dreamed of making your own video game? Do you want to know more about how the computers we use everyday work?

In blueshift’s coding club, aimed at students in Year 2 and 3, we will be building our programming and computing knowledge while creating fun games and animations in Scratch, a visual block-based coding language (https://scratch.mit.edu/).

Scratch has an easy-to-use drag-and-drop interface that gives new coders the tools to rapidly create and experiment with code. Our dedicated teachers will guide students through a set of projects teaching basic coding concepts, which will be then applied as they create games and animations.

Students will also learn about electronics and computation beyond the screen with some hands-on lessons in robotics!

The class is limited to 16 places.

For any questions, please email us at hello@blueshiftcoding.com or ring us at 0203 176 4660

name: After School Club: The Harrodian School

short_description:
Advanced Crafty  Coders

Course Description

Welcome to the world of coding!

Our Advanced Crafty Coders will take their coding to the next level as they move from block-based coding to text-based coding. We will be learning BitsBox, a version of JavaScript developed specifically with kids in mind! For more information about BitsBox see www.bitsbox.com.

 

Through this 11 week course, our dedicated teachers will guide coders through exciting projects, showing them how to create their own apps! Coders will build their computer literacy beyond the keyboard and mouse interface as they learn how to develop interactive content for touch devices, such as phones and tablets.

Achievements and outcomes

Coders will develop their knowledge of coding concepts and computational thinking while making fun games and apps which they can show off on any touch device!

Topics covered

  • X-Y coordinate systems: learning about the pixels on our screens
  • Text based coding: instructing the computer with text
  • Touch interfaces: creating content for touch devices
  • Core coding concepts: conditions, loops, and variables
  • Algorithms: concepts and application

Pre-requisites

This is an intermediate class and coders must have basic computer literacy and have used a block-based coding language. Please contact us with any queries about whether your child will be suited to this class.

Laptops
We operate a BYOL (bring your own laptop) policy. We will have a few laptops available to borrow for those who absolutely cannot get their hands on one. Please be in touch should you require one.
description: Our advanced Crafty Coders will test out their coding chops by creating games and stories using text-based coding (a more grown up version of what the beginner coders will be doing). We will be using a version of JavaScript called BitsBox that has been created just for kids!
